{{Year nav topic5|1525|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1525'''.
==Events== *''Il Petrarco'', Allesandro Vellutello's edition of [[Petrarch]] which will be reprinted 29 times this century, is first published.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kennedy|first=William J.|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j7tj_XxmLwIC&printsec=frontcover#PPA121,M1 |chapter=Petrarchan poetics|editor=Kennedy, George Alexander|title=The Cambridge History of Literary Criticism|volume=3|page=114|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1999|isbn=0-521-30008-8|accessdate=2009-05-27|display-editors=etal}}</ref> *First printing of the anonymous early 14th century poem ''King Alexander''.<ref name=cocel>{{cite book|editor=Cox, Michael|title=The Concise Oxford Chronology of English Literature|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-860634-6}}</ref> *[[William Tyndale]]'s [[New Testament]] [[Bible translation]] into English is made; printed copies reach England in [[1526 in literature|1526]]. *[[Laurentian Library]] in [[Florence]] designed by [[Michelangelo]].
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Pietro Bembo]] – ''[[:it:Prose nelle quali si ragiona della volgar lingua|Prose nelle quali si ragiona della volgar lingua]]'' (''Prose della volgar lingua'') *[[Albrecht Dürer]] – ''Underweysung der Messung mit dem Zirckel und Richtscheyt'' (literally, "Instructions for Measuring with Compass and Ruler"; also known as ''The Four Books on Measurement'' or ''The Painter's Manual'') *[[Francesco Giorgi]] – ''De harmonia mundi totius'' *[[Martin Luther]] – ''[[On the Bondage of the Will]]'' (''De Servo Arbitrio'') *[[Paracelsus]] – ''De septem puncti idolotriae christianae'' (On the Seven Points of Christian Idolatry) *[[Antonio Pigafetta]] – ''Relazione del primo viaggio intorno al mondo'' (Report on the First Voyage Around the World; partial publication in Paris) *''The [[Twelve Articles]]: The Just and Fundamental Articles of All the Peasantry and Tenants of Spiritual and Temporal Powers by Whom They Think Themselves Oppressed''
===Drama=== *[[Niklaus Manuel Deutsch I]] – ''Der Ablasskrämer'' *[[Niccolò Machiavelli]] – ''[[Clizia]]''
===Poetry=== {{main|1525 in poetry}}
==Births== *March 25 – [[Richard Edwardes]], English choral singer, poet and playwright (died [[1566 in literature|1566]]) *[[Pir Roshan]] (بايزيد انصاري), [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] warrior poet (died 1582/5) *[[Jan van Casembroot]], Flemish noble and poet (died [[1568 in literature|1568]]) *Approximate date **[[Hans Wilhelm Kirchhof]], German [[Landsknecht]], [[baroque]] poet and translator (died c.[[1602 in literature|1602]]) **[[Louise Labé]], French poet (died [[1566 in literature|1566]])
==Deaths== *May 27 – [[Thomas Müntzer]], German Protestant theologian, radical economist and poet (born c.[[1489 in literature|1489]]) (executed) *Approximate date – [[Jean Lemaire de Belges]], Walloon poet and historian resident in France (born c.[[1473 in literature|1473]])
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1525 In Literature}} [[Category:1525]] [[Category:1525 books]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1602|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1602'''.
==Events== *[[February 2]] – The [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]] perform ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' at the [[Middle Temple]] in London. *May – [[Henry Wotton]] returns to [[Florence]] having disclosed a plot to murder King [[James VI of Scotland]].<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Wotton, Henry|last=Lee|first=Sidney|authorlink=Sidney Lee|volume=63}}</ref> *[[May 4]] – [[Richard Hakluyt]] is installed as prebendary of [[Dean and Chapter of Westminster|Westminster Abbey]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard S. Westfall|title=Hakluyt, Richard|url=http://galileo.rice.edu/Catalog/NewFiles/hakluyt.html|publisher=The Galileo Project|year=1995|accessdate=21 April 2007}}</ref> *[[November 8]] – The [[Bodleian Library]] at the [[University of Oxford]] opens to scholars.
==New books== ===Prose=== *Tommaso Campanella – ''[[The City of the Sun]]'' (a philosophical work, one of the most important utopias) *[[Thomas Campion]] – ''Observations in the Art of English Poetry'' *[[Richard Carew (antiquary)|Richard Carew]] – ''A Survey of Cornwall'' *Sir [[Hugh Plat]] – ''[[Delightes for Ladies]]'' (book of recipes and household hints)
===Drama=== *Anonymous – ''[[A Larum for London|A Larum for London, or The Siedge of Antwerpe with the]]'' ''{{not a typo|ventrous}} actes and valorous deeds of the lame soldier'' published *[[Henry Chettle]] – ''Hoffmann'' *[[John Davies of Hereford]] – ''Mirum in Modum'' *[[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]] (with [[Thomas Middleton]]?) – ''[[Blurt, Master Constable|Blurt, Master Constable, or The Spaniards Night-Walke]]'' published *[[Ben Jonson]] – ''[[The Poetaster]]'' published *[[David Lyndsay (poet)|Sir David Lyndsay]] (died c. 1555) – ''Humanity and Sensuality'' and ''[[A Satire of the Three Estates]]'' published *[[John Marston (poet)|John Marston]] – ''[[Antonio and Mellida]]'' published *[[William Shakespeare]] – ''[[Hamlet]]'' performed (latest date), ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'' published *"W.S." – ''[[Thomas Lord Cromwell]]'' published<ref name="RSC Collab">{{cite book|author=Shakespeare, William|title=Collaborative Plays|series=The RSC Shakespeare|location=Basingstoke|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=2013|isbn=978-1-137-27144-0|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
===Poetry=== {{main|1602 in poetry}} *[[Giambattista Marino]] – ''Le Rime'' *[[Cristóbal de Virués]] – ''El Monserrate segundo''
==Births== *[[March 29]] – [[John Lightfoot]], English theologian (died [[1675 in literature|1675]]) *[[April 30]] – [[Robert Baillie]], Scottish divine and historian (died [[1662 in literature|1662]]) *[[May 2]] – [[Athanasius Kircher]], German scholar (died [[1680 in literature|1680]]) *[[May 10]] – [[Samuel Newman]], American Biblical commentator (died [[1663 in literature|1663]]) *October or November – [[Dudley North, 4th Baron North|Dudley North]], English poet, writer and politician (died [[1677 in literature|1677]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Juan Pérez de Montalbán]], Spanish dramatist and poet (died [[1638 in literature|1638]]) *''Approximate year'' – [[Owen Feltham]], English essayist (died [[1668 in literature|1668]])
==Deaths== *[[February 13]] – [[Alexander Nowell]], English theologian (born c. 1507) *[[September 14]] – [[Jean Passerat]], French poet and satirist (born [[1534 in literature|1534]]) *[[October 13]] – [[Franciscus Junius (the elder)]], Swiss theologian (born [[1545 in literature|1545]]) *[[October 30]] – [[Jean-Jacques Boissard]], French poet (born [[1528 in literature|1528]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Jean Pithou]], French legal writer (born [[1534 in literature|1534]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1602 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1687|literature}}
This article lists of the literary events and publications in '''1687'''.
==Events== *A [[Latin]] edition of the works of [[Confucius]] is published in Paris, the first translation of his works into any Western language. ''Confucian Sinarum Philosophus'' is the work of [[Jesuit]] scholars and [[Chinese people|Chinese]] converts to Christianity.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Spence|first1=Jonathan D.|title=What Confucius Said|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/1997/04/10/what-confucius-said/|website=The New York Review of Books|accessdate=12 April 2018|language=en|date=10 April 1997}}</ref> *The [[Académie française]] publishes the first sections of its ''[[Dictionnaire de l'Académie française|Dictionnaire]]'' in [[Frankfurt]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Dictionaries of the Académie française (17th to 20th Century)|url=https://classiques-garnier.com/dictionaries-of-the-academie-francaise-17th-to-20th-century.html|website=Classiques Garnier|accessdate=12 April 2018}}</ref>
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Antoine Furetière]] – ''Couches de l'Académie'' *[[Ihara Saikaku]] **''[[The Great Mirror of Male Love]]'' (男色大鑑, ''Nanshoku Ōkagami'') **''Transmission of the Martial Arts'' (武道伝来記, ''Budō Denraiki'') *[[Gerard Langbaine]] – ''Momus Triumphans, or the Plagiaries of the English Stage Exposed'' *[[Isaac Newton]] – ''[[Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica]] (Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy)'' *[[Charles Perrault]] – ''Le Siècle de Louis le Grand (The Century of Louis the Great)'' *[[George Savile, 1st Marquess of Halifax]] – ''Letter to a Dissenter''
===Drama=== *[[Aphra Behn]] – ''The Emperor of the Moon'' *Sir [[Charles Sedley]] – ''Bellamira, or The Mistress'' *[[Nahum Tate]]: **''The History of King Lear'' (adapted from [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[King Lear|Lear]]'', but with a happy ending) **''The Island Princess'' (adapted from [[John Fletcher (playwright)|Fletcher]]'s ''[[The Island Princess|Island Princess]]'')
===Poetry=== *[[John Dryden]] – ''[[The Hind and the Panther]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=Beast epic - literature|url=https://www.britannica.com/art/beast-epic#ref41752|website=Encyclopedia Britannica|accessdate=12 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> *[[Matthew Prior]] – ''The Hind and the Panther Transversed to the Story of the Country and the City Mouse''<ref>{{cite web|title=Collection Highlight: Dryden, The Hind and the Panther|url=http://rbscp.lib.rochester.edu/4423|website=rbscp.lib.rochester.edu|accessdate=12 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==Births== *[[March 7]] – [[Jean Lebeuf]], French historian (died [[1760 in literature|1760]]) *[[June 24]] – [[Johann Albrecht Bengel]], German classicist and theologian (died [[1752 in literature|1752]]) *[[August 26]] – [[Henry Carey (writer)|Henry Carey]], English poet and dramatist (died [[1743 in literature|1743]]) *[[November 7]] – [[William Stukeley]], English antiquary (died [[1765 in literature|1765]])
==Deaths== *[[February 16]] – [[Charles Cotton]], English poet and translator (born [[1630 in literature|1630]]) *[[March 27]] – [[Edward Sheldon (translator)|Edward Sheldon]], English translator of religious works (born [[1599 in literature|1599]]) *[[March 28]] – [[Constantijn Huygens]], Dutch poet and composer (born [[1596 in literature|1596]]) *[[September 1]] – [[Henry More]], English philosopher (born [[1614 in literature|1614]]) *[[November 3]] - [[René Rapin]], French Jesuit writer (born [[1621 in literature|1621]])<ref>{{cite web|title=René Rapin (1621-1687)|url=http://data.bnf.fr/12142104/rene_rapin/|website=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=12 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> *[[November 7]] – [[Isaac Orobio de Castro]], Portuguese Jewish philosopher and apologist (born c. 1617) *[[December 16]] – [[William Petty]], English economist and philosopher (born [[1623 in literature|1623]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[George Dalgarno]], Scottish linguist (born [[1626 in literature|1626]])<ref>{{cite web|title=Dalgarno, George 1626?-1687|url=http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n81098829/|website=Worldcat|accessdate=12 April 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{for|the Slovak football team|FC Petržalka akadémia}}
'''Artmedia''' was one of the first scientific projects concerning the relationship between art, technology, philosophy and [[aesthetics]]. It was founded in 1985 at the [[University of Salerno]]. For over two decades, until 2009, dozens of projects, studies, exhibitions and conferences on new technologies<ref>In addition to the ten international "Artmedia" conferences, which took place in Salerno and Paris from 1985 to 2008, the Laboratory has led to numerous other initiatives and events, such as "L'immaginario tecnologico", 1984 (conference and exhibition); "Technettronica", 1989 (Exhibition about the Aesthetics of Communication); "Estetica e antropologia", 1983 (International Symposium); "Tecnologie e forme nell'arte e nella scienza", 2003 (International Symposium); "New Technologies: Roy Ascott, Maurizio Bolognini, Fred Forest, Richard Kriesche, Mit Mitropoulos", Museo del Sannio, 2003 (Exhibition on the Aesthetics of Communication); "Estetica e tecnologia", 1987 (Symposium); "L'immateriale in piazza" (Aitiani, Forest, Mitropoulos, Grossi, Prado), Naples, 1992 (Exhibition on the Aesthetics of Communication); "Un'estetica per i media" 1989 (RAI, Dipartimento Scuola Educazione, TV program); "Cartacarbone", 1990 (radio program); "Coincidences", 1995 (Aesthetics journal, in French); "Epiphaneia", 1995-1996 (Aesthetics journal, in Italian). See ''Edition spéciale Artmedia'', "Art Press", Paris, 2002.</ref> made Artmedia a reference point for many internationally renowned scholars and artists,<ref>A. R., ''Des hauts et débats. Colloque Artmedia VIII'', "Liberation", November 29, 2002, p. 13; ''Dossier: De l’esthétique de la communication au Net Art'', "Art Press", 285, November 2002, pp. 37-43.</ref> and contributed to the growing cultural interest in the aesthetics of [[New media|media]], the aesthetics of [[Computer network|networks]], and their [[ethical]] and [[Anthropology|anthropological]] implications.
==Beginnings and international events== Since the late 1970s, a permanent ''Seminar of the Aesthetics of Media and Communication'' has been directed by its founder [[Mario Costa (philosopher)|Mario Costa]] at the University of Salerno. The basic principles of the aesthetics of technological communication were identified and conceptualized in 1983.<ref>The history of the "aesthetics of communication", especially upon its debut in the 1980s, is recorded in the book by Mario Costa,''The Aesthetics of Communication. Aesthetic use of simultaneity at a distance'', Rome, Castelvecchi, 1999; its basic principles, formulated by Costa, were expressed for the first time in ''News and Notes'', published by the International Center of Aesthetic Communication, Salerno, 1986.</ref> A conference on "Technological Imaginary", held in 1984 at the Museo del Sannio in [[Benevento]], discussed the issue of the new relationship between art and technology and the consequent need to re-evaluate aesthetics, warning that "all our future existence will be played at the crossroads between technology and imaginary".<ref>"Aa. Vv., ''L’immaginario tecnologico'', Museo del Sannio, Benevento, p. 8.</ref>
The comprehensive relationship between art and [[technoscience]], technology, and philosophy has also been the theoretical subject of the ten international "Artmedia" conferences which were held in Salerno and Paris between 1985 and 2008. Particularly relevant were conferences held in Paris between 2002 and 2008, which took place at the [[Ecole Normale Supérieure]], the [[Bibliotheque Nationale de France]] (BNF) and the Institut National d'Histoire de l 'Art (INHA), with the partnership of the Société Française d'Esthétique, the [[Université du Québec à Montréal]], the [[University of Toronto]], the [[Universidade de São Paulo]], the [[Sorbonne University|Université de Paris 1 Sorbonne]], and the U.S. magazine [[Leonardo (journal)|Leonardo]].<ref>See Mario Costa, Fred Forest (eds) (2011), ''Ethique, esthétique, communication technologique dans l'art contemporain ou le destin du sens'', Paris: Institut National Audiovisuel, Editions L'Harmattan, and ''Dossier Artmedia VIII'', in "Ligeia", Paris, 2002.</ref>
==Continuous debate between artists and theorists== [[Image:DeKerckhove Berger Costa ArtmediaIV 1992.JPG|right|thumb|[[Derrick de Kerckhove]], [[René Berger]] and [[Mario Costa (philosopher)|Mario Costa]], Artmedia IV (1992)]] [[Image:Bolognini Kriesche Costa Kac ArtmediaVII 1999.JPG|right|thumb|[[Maurizio Bolognini]], Richard Kriesche, [[Mario Costa (philosopher)|Mario Costa]] and [[Eduardo Kac]], Artmedia VII (1999)]] Artmedia wanted to gather theorists and artists from all over the world and encourage both joint and complementary work, beginning with the need to give attention to theoretical and artistic practices and developing both together. These also contributed towards spreading the spirit of the project, both in a number of festivals and shows, and through their own artworks and research.<ref>Antonella Fimiani, ''Arte & tecnologia, la frontiera-Salerno'', in "Il Mattino", November 24, 1999, p. 23; Sylvie Lisiecki e Marie Saladin, ''Fenetrês sur les arts numériques'', in "Croniques de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France", 46, 2008.</ref>
Theorists who worked with Artmedia and participated in its activities included [[Bernard Stiegler]], [[René Berger]], [[Abraham Moles]], [[Derrick De Kerckhove]], [[Pierre Levy]], Gillo Dorfles, [[Paul Virilio]], [[Frank Popper]], [[Roger Malina]], Daniel Charles, José Jiménez, Anne Cauquelin, [[Edgar Morin]], [[Thierry de Duve]], [[Catherine Millet]], Filiberto Menna, Andreas Broeckmann, Rudolf zur Lippe, [[Edmond Couchot]], Dominique Chateau, Yannick Geffroy, Philippe Queau, Arlindo Machado, Tetsuo Kogawa, and Bernard Teyssedre.
Artists included [[Fred Forest]], [[Roy Ascott]], [[Takahiko Iimura]], [[Maurizio Bolognini]], [[Tom Klinkowstein]], Tom Sherman, [[Eduardo Kac]], Enzo Minarelli, [[James Dashow]], [[Peter D'Agostino]], Mit Mitropoulos, [[Shawn Brixey]], Bruno Di Bello, [[Antoni Muntadas]], [[Orlan]], Kit Galloway, [[David Rokeby]], [[Miguel Chevalier]], [[Norman White]], Richard Kriesche, Olivier Auber, [[Caterina Davinio]] and [[Casey Reas]].<ref>On the participation of artists and theorists, see in particular: Mario Costa, Fred Forest (eds) (2011), ''Ethique, esthétique, communication technologique dans l'art contemporain ou le destin du sens'', Paris: Institut National Audiovisuel, Editions L'Harmattan; Mario Costa (ed.) (2004), ''New Technologies: [[Roy Ascott]], Maurizio Bolognini, [[Fred Forest]], Richard Kriesche, Mit Mitropoulos'', Salerno: Artmedia, Museo del Sannio; ''Dossier Artmedia VIII'', in "Ligeia", Paris, 2002, pp. 21-245; ''Edition spéciale Artmedia'', "Art Press", Paris, 2002; see also the OLATS/Leonardo websites: http://www.olats.org/projetpart/artmedia/2002/mono_index.php and http://www.olats.org/projetpart/artmedia/2008/mono_index.php .</ref>
The questions raised in various projects promoted by Artmedia, in a continuous dialogue between artists and theorists, led to discussions on topics including ''Aesthetics of Communication and the anthropology of the future'' (1985), ''Global aesthetic communication'' (1986), ''Electronic performativity and the art system'' (1990), ''Neo-technological arts between aesthetics and communication'' (1992), ''Aesthetic research and technology'' (1995), ''Developments in aesthetics: change or mutation?'' (1999), ''From the Aesthetics of Communication to Net art'' (2002), and ''Ethics, aesthetics and techno-communication. The future of meaning'' (2008).
All Artmedia symposiums have been followed by many publications. For the two held in Paris, a complete video recording is also available, and can be viewed at the [[Institut National de l'Audiovisuel]].
An assessment of 25 years of Artmedia activity was made into a seminar on ''The aesthetic object of the future'', held at the [[University of Salerno]] in 2009. The Artmedia project produced a large number of publications and documents that are being catalogued, with a view to their proper placement and use.
==Key areas of investigation== * [[Electronic music]] * [[Photographic film|Photochemical]] versus [[digital photography]] * Aesthetics of [[radio]] * [[Electroacoustic music|Electroacoustic]] poetry * [[Electronic literature|Electronic writing and poetry]] * [[Video art]] * [[Generative art]] and [[software art]] * [[Computer art]] * Aesthetics of [[computer networks|networks]] * [[Net art]] * Aesthetics of [[virtual artifact|virtual]] * [[Telerobotics]] and remote [[interactivity]] * Aesthetics of (technological) flux versus aesthetics of form
==Proceedings and catalogs== '''Artmedia I''' (1985) *Mario Costa (ed.) (1985), ''Artmedia'', Salerno: Opera Universitaria di Salerno (Catalog, pp. 206).<ref>On Artmedia I, see also: ''Video Magazine'', IV, 43, 1985, p.13; Mario Costa, ''Artmedia, Salerne et l’esthétique de la communication'', "Plus Moins Zéro", Editeur S. Rona, 1, Bruxelles 1985, pp.3-4; ''C.A. Art et technologies de la communication à Salerne'', in "L'art vivante", 11 nouvelle série, Paris 1985, pp. 15 e 54; Mario Costa, ''Video Images και Media-performances'', in "CAMERA review", Athens 1986, pp. 47-49; ''Artmedia: dateci un video e solleveremo l'arte'', in "Il Mattino", May 18, 1985, p. 6; Angelo Trimarco, ''Lontano dal pennello'', in "Il Mattino", July 8, 1985, p. 3; Rino Mele, ''Il video è un'arte che viene da lontano'', in "Paese Sera", July 15, 1985, p. 5; Vitaliano Corbi, ''Artmedia: rassegna di estetica del video e della comunicazione'', in “”Paese Sera” (Napoli), May 20. 1985, p. 3; Carla Errico, ''Sette giorni per parlare di video-comunicazioni'', in "Il Mattino", May 19, 1985, p. 17; Natan Karczmar, ''ART MEDIA en Italie'', in "Réalités d’Israel", 1985, p. 18; Stella Cervasio, ''Artmedia, l'arte del video'', in "La Torre", 1985, p. 3.</ref>
'''Artmedia II''' (1986) *Mario Costa (ed.) (1986), ''Artmedia, II Convegno Internazionale di Estetica della comunicazione'', Salerno: Università di Salerno (Catalog, pp. 80).<ref>In addition, see Gianpiero Gamaleri, ''Pennello elettronico per il video artista'', in "Radiocorriere TV", 8, 1986, pp. 102-103; Valerio Caprara, ''A Salerno "Art media", ovvero video e dintorni'', in "Il Mattino", May 27, 1986, p. 12; Filiberto Menna, ''Estetica della comunicazione e video arte a Salerno. Quando evento e trasmissione coincidono'', in "Paese Sera", June 9, 1986, p. 3; ''Video Magazine'', 55, 1986, p. 13; Mario Forgione, ''Tanta nostalgia per la radio. Radio/Iniziativa al Grenoble'', in "Il Mattino", June 13, 1986, p. 10; Alfredo D'Agnese, ''L'estetica del video'', in "Il Giornale di Napoli", May 22, 1986, p. 11.</ref>
'''Artmedia III''' (1990) *Mario Costa (ed.) (1990), ''Artmedia. Terzo Convegno Internazionale di Estetica dei Media e della Comunicazione. Catalogo'', Salerno: Università degli Studi di Salerno (Catalog, pp. 80). *Mario Costa (ed.) (1990), ''Artmedia. Terzo Convegno Internazionale di Estetica dei Media e della Comunicazione. Atti'', Salerno: Università degli Studi di Salerno (Proceedings, pp. 96).<ref>On Artmedia III, see also: Vincenzo Cuomo, ''Teoria e performances al convegno "Artmedia"'', in "Mass Media", 5, 1990, pp. 68-70; Fred Forest, ''Colloque Artmedia III'', in "Communication et langages", vol. 86, 1990, pp. 119-120; Mario Costa, ''La nuova immagine della comunicazione'', in "Il Mattino", November 6, 1990, Libri & Arte, p. IV; Mario Lignano, ''Il futuro è presente'', in "Enne", 41, 1990, p. 14; Antonio Marmo, ''Il mandala nel computer'', in "Gazetta di Salerno", November 22, 1990, p. 8.</ref>
'''Artmedia IV''' (1992) *Mario Costa (ed.) (1992), ''Nuovi media e sperimentazione d’artista'', Naples: Edizioni Scientifiche Italiane (including Artmedia IV Proceedings, pp. 1–156).<ref>See also Riccardo Notte, ''L'arte multimediale e l'estetica della comunicazione'', in "Roma", November 19, 1992, p. 15.</ref>
'''Artmedia V''' (1995) *Università degli Studi di Salerno, Comune di Salerno (1995), ''Quinto Convegno Internazionale di Estetica dei Media e della Comunicazione'', Salerno (maquette).
'''Artmedia VI''' (1997) *Università degli Studi di Salerno, Fondazione Filiberto Menna (1997), ''Artmedia VI'', Salerno (maquette).<ref>On Artmedia VI, see also: Annibale Elia, ''Arti moderne, kermesse a Salerno. In rassegna ipertesti e iper-media: la postmodernità'', in "Il Mattino", November 26, 1997, p. 33; Salvatore Sabatino, ''Artmedia tra ateneo e città'', in "Cronache del Mezzogiorno", November 27, 1997, p. 7.</ref>
'''Artmedia VII''' (1999) *Mario Costa (ed.) (1999), ''Artmedia VII, Settimo Convegno Internazionale di Estetica dei Media e della Comunicazione'', Salerno: Università degli Studi di Salerno (Catalog, pp. 60).<ref>On Artmedia VII see also: Claudia Bonasi, ''Artmedia, tra videoistallazioni e scrittura digitale'', in "Corriere del Mezzogiorno", November 24, 1999, p. 2; Patrizia Sessa, ''Artmedia. Linguaggio artistico d’avanguardia'', in "La Città", November 24, 1999, p. 37; Antonella Fimiani, ''Arte & tecnologia, la frontiera-Salerno'', in "Il Mattino", November 24, 1999, p. 23; Antonella Croce, ''I media e la comunicazione'', in "Cronache del Mezzogiorno", November 24, 1999, p. 33; Enrica Tifatino, ''Mutamenti estetici e comunicazione'', in "Il Denaro", November 27, 1999, p. 57; Re.Ga., ''Al via la settima edizione di Art media'', in "Cronache del Mezzogiorno", November 20, 1999, p. 27.</ref>

{{Infobox artefact | name = Carthage Treasure | image = [[File:Carthage (9).JPG|300px]] | image_caption = Part of the Carthage Treasure as currently displayed in the British Museum | material = Silver | size = | writing = | created = 4th century AD | discovered = | location = [[British Museum]], [[London]] | id = | registration = }} The '''Carthage Treasure''' is a [[Roman Empire|Roman]] silver hoard, which was found in [[Tunis]], [[Tunisia]], at the site of the ancient city of [[Carthage]]. The treasure principally consists of silver tableware and jewellery, most of which is now held at the [[British Museum]].<ref name=bm>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?place=31013&plaA=31013-3-2 British Museum Collection], British Museum, retrieved April 2014</ref>
==Discovery== The hoard was unearthed in the nineteenth century at the Hill of St Louis in Carthage, which at the time of its deposition was the largest city of [[Africa (Roman province)|Africa Proconsulare]].<ref name=bowl/> Most of the treasure was purchased by Sir [[Augustus Wollaston Franks]], a senior curator at the British Museum, who bequeathed it to the museum upon his death in 1897. However, a small part of the treasure can be found in the [[Louvre]], including one of the silver covered bowls.<ref>[http://cartelen.louvre.fr/cartelen/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=9434 Louvre Collection], Louvre Collection, retrieved April 2014</ref>
==Dating and attribution== [[Image:Carthage (2).JPG|thumb|A bowl with low relief scenes of shepherds]] Dating to the second half of the fourth century AD, the Carthage Treasure comprises 31 different objects, primarily luxury silver tableware and jewellery that must have belonged to a wealthy Roman family who for some reason decided to [[hoard|bury it for safe-keeping]]. This may have been because of the religious feud around the year 400 but it is more likely that the treasure was hidden from the [[Vandals]]. The Vandals, led by [[Gaiseric]], invaded Africa Proconsulare from Spain in 429 and in 439 the city [[Battle of Carthage (439)|became]] capital of the [[Vandal Kingdom]].<ref name=caygill>{{cite book|last=Caygill|first=Marjorie|title=The British Museum A–Z Companion|year=2001|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1135968942|page=68|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1135968942}}</ref> Inscribed in the centre of one of the dishes around the [[tondo (art)|tondo]] is D D ICRESCONI CLARENT, which is associated with the Cresconii, a powerful Roman North African family in Carthage<ref name=bowl>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/b/bowl_from_the_carthage_treasur.aspx Bowl from the Carthage Treasure], Highlights, British Museum, retrieved 3 April 2014</ref> who are well known from deeds and records of office-holders at this time.
==Description of the treasure==
The treasure includes a pair of flat dishes (one of which identifies the family), two bowls with chased and hammered pastoral scenes in relief around the edge,<ref name=bowl /> four hemispherical [[bowl]]s with high tapering feet (two of which still have their covers), a shallow bowl with handle and [[frog]] engraved in the centre, twelve silver spoons, and a mixed collection of [[jewellery]]: a finger ring, a cameo, a pair of ear rings, several [[Engraved gem|intaglios]] and two necklaces, one made of gold, the other with precious stones.<ref name=bm/> The jewelled necklace consists of twelve polygonal emeralds, thirteen sapphires, matched by twenty five pearls all joined by gold links.<ref name=arc>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueofearly00britiala/catalogueofearly00britiala_djvu.txt ''Catalogue of early Christian antiquities and objects from the Christian East in the Department of British and mediaeval antiquities and ethnography of the British museum''], [[Ormonde Maddock Dalton|O. M. Dalton]], 1901</ref>
The family would have owned two collections of silver: One known as ''argentum potorium'' that was the drinking set and another for eating called the ''argentum escarium''. Amongst this find were several silver hemispherical lidded bowls that measure 12 cm high and 12 cm in diameter. The vessels' elegant design includes a tall base that complements the knop of the bowl's lid. The bowls also incorporate subtle [[facet]]s on the lids' curved surfaces.<ref name=coveredbowl /> Similar bowls have been found at the Roman site of [[Viminacium]] near the modern town of [[Kostolac]] in Serbia.<ref name=coveredbowl>[https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/silver-bowl-from-the-carthage-treasure/dwGIZejwDjWdNQ Silver bowl from the Carthage Treasure], British Museum, retrieved 10 January 2016</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Carthage (3).JPG| One of the necklaces (made of [[pearl]]s and [[sapphire]]s) next to the pair of ear rings Image:Carthage (4).JPG| A silver spoon with an apocalyptic Chrismon engraved in the centre Image:Carthage (5).JPG| A flat bowl with [[Latin]] inscription around the centre Image:Carthage (6).JPG| Two elaborately decorated bowls with pastoral and [[bacchic]] scenes Image:Carthage (7).JPG| Shallow bowl above three silver spoons Image:Carthage (1).JPG| One of the hemispherical covered bowls
</gallery>

Strong, Greek and Roman Silver Plate (British Museum Press, 1966) *L. Burn, The British Museum Book of Greek and Roman Art (British Museum Press, 1991) *S. Walker, Roman Art (British Museum Press, 1991)

{{notability|Organizations|date=February 2015}} The '''Connecticut Critics Circle''' is an organization of reviewers, feature writers, columnists, and broadcasters throughout [[Connecticut]], [[Massachusetts]], [[Rhode Island]], and New York. It was founded in 1990<ref>[http://www.ctcritics.org/about_us.html About Us]</ref>
==Mission statement== "To honor the actors, directors, designers and others who help make professional Connecticut theater so outstanding. ... The organization's members also meet to discuss issues regarding theater criticism. Additionally, it invites prominent guest speakers to address the membership in meetings that are open to the public."<ref>[http://www.ctcritics.org/about_us.html About Us]</ref>
==Awards== Their annual awards are considered prestigious<ref>[http://scottthompsononline.com/joseph-and-the-amazing-technicolor-dreamcoat-2/ Scott receives BEST DIRECTOR AWARD from Connecticut Critics Circle for JOSEPH]</ref>
The Tom Killen Memorial Award "is bestowed upon those who have made extraordinary contributions to Connecticut's Equity professional theater."<ref>[http://www.ctcritics.org/awards.html Awards]</ref> [[Gordon Edelstein]] won that award, among others, including Outstanding Director of a Play for Uncle Vanya in 2007.
[[Jeff Kready]] received a Connecticut Critics Circle Nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Musical,.<ref>[http://articles.courant.com/2013-05-26/entertainment/hc-connecticut-critics-circle-nominate-best-of-theater-season-20130526_1_long-wharf-theater-critics-circle-awards/4 Connecticut Critics Circle Nominate Best Of Theater Season]</ref>
[[Jeremy Jordan (stage actor)|Jeremy Jordan]] was nominated in 2008 for his role as Alex in ''[[The Little Dog Laughed]]'' at [[TheaterWorks (Hartford)|Hartford Theatreworks]]<ref>[http://boston.broadwayworld.com/article/Photo_Preview_The_Little_Dog_Laughed_at_Theater_Works_Hartford_20080121 "Photo Preview: ''The Little Dog Laughed'' at Theater Works Hartford"], BroadwayWorld.com; accessed August 19, 2014.</ref>
[[Joyce Ebert]] earned a special achievement award in 1996 for "30 years of ''outstanding contribution to a theater in Connecticut."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/30/arts/joyce-ebert-64-prolific-actress-in-stage-roles-large-and-small.html Joyce Ebert, 64, Prolific Actress In Stage Roles Large and Small]</ref>
[[David Esbjornson]]<ref>[http://www.masongross.rutgers.edu/theater/faculty/david-esbjornson David Esbjornson Chair, Department of Theater]</ref>
[[Frank Ferrante]] for his portrayal of Captain Spalding in Animal Crackers at [[Goodspeed Opera House]]<ref>[http://www.eveningwithgroucho.com/bios.html Bios at Groucho.com]</ref>
==References== <references />

{{Infobox Organization |name = CrimethInc. Ex-Workers Collective |image = CrimethInc_wordmark.png |image_border = |size = 200px |caption = CrimethInc. [[wordmark]] |motto = |purpose =The "pursuit of a freer and more joyous world"<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/ |title=CrimethInc. Ex-Workers' Collective : Home |work=Crimethinc.com |accessdate=2008-04-07 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eVzkCwAW?url=http://www.crimethinc.com/ |archivedate=February 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} </ref> |type = [[Decentralization|Decentralized]] [[anarcho-communist]] [[collective]] |membership = Voluntary association |website = [https://crimethinc.com/ crimethinc.com] }} '''CrimethInc.''', also known as '''CWC''', which stands for either "'''CrimethInc. Ex-Workers Collective'''" or "'''CrimethInc Ex-Workers Ex-Collective'''"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/texts/atoz/afterthefall.php |title=After the Fall: Analysis of the Events of September 11th 2001 |accessdate=2007-10-31 |author=The CrimethInc Ex-Workers Ex-Collective Revolutionary Task Force on Terrorism |work=Crimethinc.com |archivedate=February 11, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eW05mJBp?url=http://www.crimethinc.com/texts/atoz/afterthefall.php |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>, is a [[Decentralization|decentralized]] [[anarcho-communist]] [[collective]] of autonomous [[Clandestine cell system|cells]].<ref name="gordon"> *{{Cite conference |first=Uri |last=Gordon |authorlink=Uri Gordon |title=Liberation Now: Present-tense Dimensions of Contemporary Anarchism |booktitle=Thinking the Present : The Beginnings and Ends of Political Theory |date=27–28 May 2005 |location=University of California, Berkeley}} *{{Cite journal |last=Thompson |first=Stacy |title=Crass Commodities |journal=Popular Music & Society |issue=3 |volume=27 |date=October 2004 |pages=307–322(16) |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2822/is_3_27/ai_n6330582 |accessdate=2007-07-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080101051714/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2822/is_3_27/ai_n6330582 |archivedate=January 1, 2008 |doi=10.1080/03007760410001733152 |deadurl=yes |df= }} *{{Cite web |url=http://www.athensnews.com/issue/article.php3?story_id=28894 |title=Melee breaks out uptown at end of anarchist confab |accessdate=2007-08-01 |last=Ludwig |first=Mike |date=2007-07-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928130453/http://www.athensnews.com/issue/article.php3?story_id=28894 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |work=The Athens News |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> CrimethInc. emerged in the mid-1990s,<ref name="faq"/> initially as the hardcore [[zine]] ''[[Inside Front]]'', and began operating as a collective in 1996.<ref name="thompson">{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=Stacy |title=Punk Productions: Unfinished Business |publisher=SUNY Press |pages=109 |location=Albany |year=2004 |isbn=0-7914-6187-4}}</ref> It has since published widely read articles and zines for the anarcho-communist movement and distributed posters and books of its own publication.<ref name=brandt>{{cite web |last=Brandt |first=Jed |url=http://burning.typepad.com/burningman/2006/03/crimethinc_is_i.html |title=Crimethinc: In Love With Love Itself |work=[[Clamor (magazine)|Clamor]] |accessdate=January 14, 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5eW0gRYrS?url=http://burning.typepad.com/burningman/2006/03/crimethinc_is_i.html |archivedate=February 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
CrimethInc. cells have published books, released records, and organized national campaigns against globalization and representative democracy in favor of radical community organizing. Less public splinter groups have carried out direct action (including arson and [[hacktivism]]), hosted international conventions and other events, maintained local chapters, sparked riots, and toured with multimedia performance art or hardcore [[anarcho-punk]] musical ensembles. The collective has received national media and academic attention, as well as criticism and praise from other anarchists for its activities and philosophy. CrimethInc. has an association with the North American anarcho-punk scene due to its relationship with artists in the genre and its publishing of ''Inside Front'' as well as, more recently, the contemporary anti-capitalist movement.
==Activities== Activities by CrimethInc. cells have toured with hardcore [[anarcho-punk]] musical ensembles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.www.dailycampus.com/media/storage/paper340/news/2002/10/08/Focus/Punk-Show.Rocks.Student.Union-292057.shtml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110708221434/http://media.www.dailycampus.com/media/storage/paper340/news/2002/10/08/Focus/Punk-Show.Rocks.Student.Union-292057.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-08 |title=Punk show rocks Student Union |accessdate=2008-07-24 |last=Patterson |first=Jesse |work=The Daily Campus |publisher= |date=2002-10-08 }}</ref> In 2002, a cell in [[Olympia, Washington]] staged a five-day film festival with skill-sharing workshops and screenings.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ross |last=Raihala |title=The heArt and Film Festival |url= |work=[[The Olympian]] |date=2002-12-12}}</ref> Cells have also supported various large-scale campaigns with publicity work, including the "[[Unabomber for President]]" and the "[[Don't Just (Not) Vote]]" election campaigns as well as the protests against the [[Free Trade Area of the Americas]] of 2003 in [[Miami, Florida]].<ref>''Days of War, Nights of Love'' (2001) , Crimethinc.Workers Collective, p. 221 {{ISBN|0-9709101-0-X}}</ref><ref name="rev">{{cite book |last=Andersen |first=Mark |title=All the Power : Revolution Without Illusion |publisher=Punk Planet Books |year=2004 |isbn=978-1-888451-72-6}}</ref> Individuals adopting the CrimethInc. ''nom de guerre'' have included convicted [[Earth Liberation Front|ELF]] arsonists,<ref>{{cite news |title=3 plead guilty in attempts at arson |work=[[The Sacramento Bee]] |date=2005-10-15}}</ref> as well as [[hacktivists]] who successfully attacked the websites of [[Drug Abuse Resistance Education|DARE]], [[Republican National Committee]] and sites related to U.S. President [[George W. Bush]]'s [[George W. Bush presidential campaign, 2004|2004 re-election campaign]].<ref name=wired>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2004/08/64602 |title=Hackers Take Aim at GOP |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |accessdate=2008-02-22 |last=Schachtman |first=Noah |date=2004-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090111015944/http://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2004/08/64602 |archivedate=2009-01-11 |df= }}</ref><ref name=deagon>{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Deagon |title=GOP Sites Hit By Denial Of Service Attack; Hard To Tell Who Culprits Are |work=Investor's Business Daily |date=2004-10-22}}</ref> These activities have earned the collective irregular attention from the mainstream news media.<ref> * {{cite news |first=Chris |last=Whitehead |title=How do you say 'dese, dem, dose' in Chinese?; The Mayor's Office of |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5858110.html |publisher=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date=2007-04-13 |accessdate=2007-07-08 }} * {{cite news |first=Sarah |last=Childress |title='Hacktivists' Log On |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_kmnew/is_200408/ai_n6835339 |publisher=[[Newsweek]] |date=August 2004 |accessdate=2007-07-08}} * {{cite news |first=Irene |last=Sege |title=Pay phones may appear to be gathering dust, but some still use them |url=http://www.boston.com/lifestyle/articles/2008/03/10/busy_signals/ |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |date=2008-03-10 |accessdate=2008-03-16}}</ref> In 2010, several CrimethInc. cells worked in collaboration with other [[anti-capitalist]]s and [[anarchist]]s to launch international Steal Something From Work Day, which coincides with the United States [[Tax Day]].
===Publications===
[[File:Days of war, nights of love ne plus ultra edition.jpg|thumb|left|"[[Ne plus ultra]]" edition of ''Days of War, Nights of Love'', CrimethInc.'s 2001 [[manifesto]].]]
The creation of propaganda has been described as the collective's core function.<ref name="harper's">{{cite journal|last=Power |first=Matthew |date=March 2008 |title=Mississippi Drift |journal=[[Harper's Magazine]] |pages=54–63 |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/crimethinc_in_harpers.pdf |accessdate=2008-03-10 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511151948/http://www.crimethinc.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/crimethinc_in_harpers.pdf |archivedate=2008-05-11 |df= }}</ref> Among their best-known publications are the books ''Days of War, Nights of Love'', ''Expect Resistance'', ''Evasion'', ''Recipes for Disaster: An Anarchist Cookbook'' the pamphlets ''To Change Everything: an Anarchist Appeal'' (available in paper, PDF and video form) and ''Fighting For Our Lives'' (of which, to date, they claim to have printed 600,000 copies),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/blog/2008/05/28/fourth-ffol-printing-hits-the-streets/ |title=Fourth FFOL Printing Hits the Streets |work=CrimethInc. Far East Blog |date=2008-05-28 |accessdate=2008-06-14 |author=pfm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080601013828/http://www.crimethinc.com/blog/2008/05/28/fourth-ffol-printing-hits-the-streets/ |archive-date=2008-06-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> the [[hardcore punk]]/political [[zine]] ''Inside Front'', and the music of hardcore punk bands. Several websites are maintained by individual cells, including Crimethinc.com, operated by the Far East Cell, which hosts propaganda, excerpts from available publications, and a blog of the activities of other cells. CrimethInc. is connected to publishing collectives/organizations with similar ideas, notably the [[Curious George Brigade]], which has written a number of publications including ''Anarchy in the Age of Dinosaurs''. In 2005, they began publishing a half-gloss journal, ''Rolling Thunder'', with the byline "An Anarchist Journal of Dangerous Living", which released its eighth issue in 2009. CrimethInc. texts have received wide coverage in the anarchist media and in academic publications,<ref> *{{Cite journal |last=Clark |first=Dylan |year=2004 |title=The Raw and the Rotten: Punk Cuisine |journal=Ethnology |volume=43}} *{{Cite book |last=Doy |first=Gen |title=Picturing the Self |publisher=I. B. Tauris |location=London |year=2004 |isbn=1-85043-413-1}} *{{Cite journal |last=Edwards |first=Ferne |author2=Mercer, David |date=November 2007 |title=Gleaning from Gluttony: an Australian youth subculture confronts the ethics of waste |journal=[[Australian Geographer]] |volume=38 |issue=3 |pages=279–296 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |doi=10.1080/00049180701639174 |url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a783694781~db=all}} *{{Cite journal |last=Dunne |first=Stephen |first2=Eleni |last2=Karamali |first3=Stevphen |last3=Shukaitis |year=2005 |title=Inscribing Organized Resistance |journal=Ephemera |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=562–567 |issn=1473-2866}}</ref><ref name=gndr>{{cite journal |last=Nicholas |first=Lucy |date=Spring 2007 |title=Approaches to Gender, Power and Authority in Contemporary Anarcho-punk: Poststructuralist Anarchism? |journal=ESharp |issue=9 |pages= |issn=1742-4542 |url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/media/media_41219_en.pdf |accessdate=2008-04-07 |format=PDF}}</ref> and have been used as reading materials for university courses on anarchism.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Conger |first=Chloe |url=http://daily.stanford.edu/article/2002/4/29/studentLeadsCourseOnAnarchy |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070429184048/http://daily.stanford.edu/article/2002/4/29/studentLeadsCourseOnAnarchy |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-04-29 |title=Student leads course on anarchy |accessdate=2008-07-24 |journal=[[The Stanford Daily]] |date=2002-04-29}} </ref>
===Convergences=== {{quotebox| |align=right |width=15% |title=Convergence locations |quote= * [[Des Moines, Iowa]] (2002) * [[Louisville, Kentucky]] (2003) * Des Moines, Iowa (2004) * [[Bloomington, Indiana]] (2005) * [[Winona, Minnesota]] (2006) * [[Athens, Ohio]] (2007) * [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] (2008) * [[Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] (2009) }}
Since the summer of 2002, CrimethInc. has hosted annual conventions, termed "convergences", open to anyone. Typically featuring the performances of traveling theatrical troupes, musicians, direct-action and [[mutual aid (politics)|mutual-aid]] workshops from individual participants, the few-days-long camping trips have attracted coverage in newspaper articles,<ref name=gouss/> initiated multiple [[Reclaim the Streets]] actions, mobilized large [[Critical Mass (cycling)|Critical Mass]] events, and catalyzed many other activities.<ref name=ao7/>
The 2007 convergence in [[Athens, Ohio]], saw an impromptu [[street party]] which resulted in arrests on minor charges.<ref name=gouss> {{cite web |url=https://www.athensmessenger.com/news/anarchist-answers-to-riot-charge/article_c3e000d9-93b2-5248-b16e-ff2867b0d4e3.html |title=Anarchist answers to riot charge |work=Athens Messenger |accessdate=2008-02-22 |last=Goussetis |first=Elizabeth |date=2007-07-31 }} </ref> ''The Athens News'' characterized the convergence as "a sort of networking, resume-swapping opportunity for would-be radicals, free-thinkers, [[Levellers]], [[Diggers]], [[Neo-Luddism|Neo-Luddites]] and other assorted malcontents."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.athensnews.com/news/local/good-going-you-left-town-for-the-summer-and-missed/article_fbdcc78d-64dd-5cff-b2e0-8d368406181a.html |title=Good going; you left town for the summer and missed everything |publisher=The Athens News |accessdate=2008-02-25 |last=Phillips |first=Jim |date=2007-09-04 }}</ref> It is typical of these gatherings to require that all attendees have something to contribute to the momentum: whether it is bringing food or equipment to share, leading a discussion group, or providing materials with which to write to [[political prisoner]]s. There has been a pattern of promoting convergences as festivals, reminiscent of barnstorming [[flying circus]]es and travelling sideshows.<ref name=ao7>{{cite web|url=http://www.infoshop.org/inews/article.php?story=2007073009151431 |title=Athens, Ohio: Police attack Crimethinc conference |work=Infoshop News |publisher=[[Infoshop.org]] |accessdate=2008-04-28 |date=2007-07-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523102836/http://www.infoshop.org/inews/article.php?story=2007073009151431 |archivedate=2011-05-23 |df= }}</ref>
''[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]]'' journalist Matthew Power described the 2006 convergence in [[Winona, Minnesota]] as follows: {{quote|text=Several hundred young anarchists from around the country had train-hopped and hitchhiked there to attend the annual event known as the CrimethInc Convergence...Grimy and feral-looking, the CrimethInc kids squatted in small groups around a clearing....[they] were in the middle of several days of self-organized workshops, seminars, and discussions, ranging from the [[mutualism (economic theory)|mutualist banking]] theories of the nineteenth-century anarchist philosopher [[Pierre-Joseph Proudhon]], to an introductory practicum on lock-picking, to a class on making one's own menstrual pads .... CrimethInc's adherents had come together there because they wanted to live their lives as some sort of solution. They saw 'the revolution' not as a final product but as an ongoing process; they wanted not just to destroy the capitalist system but to create something livable in its place.<ref name="harper's"/>|sign=Matthew Power|source=''[[Harper's Magazine]]'', March 2008}}
These convergences have been hosted by different groups within the collective each time, typically based on the initiative of local enthusiasts. Every year a different set of policy requests is released from locals in the field, typically encouraging a sober, consensus-based space in which no financial transactions are made. The one firm rule has been "No police informants," a regulation which has been ignored by the [[FBI]]. Information gathered by FBI informants at CrimethInc. convergences (in 2004, 2005, and 2008) contributed to the convictions of [[Eric McDavid]] and his associates, as well as [[2008 Republican National Convention]] protester Matthew DePalma.<ref>http://www.startribune.com/local/stpaul/41070787.html?elr=KArks:DCiUtEia_nDaycUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUU {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607063219/http://www.startribune.com/local/stpaul/41070787.html?elr=KArks%3ADCiUtEia_nDaycUiD3aPc%3A_Yyc%3AaUU |date=2011-06-07 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/Conventions/story?id=5718900&page=1 |title=Michigan Man Accused of RNC Molotov Cocktail Plot |author=ABC News |work=ABC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://static.kovr.viacomlocalnetworks.com/~kovr/affidavit.pdf |archivedate=2007-01-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070111192140/http://static.kovr.viacomlocalnetworks.com/~kovr/affidavit.pdf |title=Confidential Source "Anna"-issued affidavit |accessdate=2008-07-21 |format=[[.pdf]] |work=United States District Court Eastern District of California}}</ref>
In 2010, CrimethInc. announced the ''We Are Everywhere'' campaign of national tours and events in lieu of the traditional convergence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/blog/2010/06/03/august-2010-we-are-everywhere/ |title=August 2010: We Are Everywhere - CrimethInc. Far East Blog |publisher=}}</ref> In 2015, CrimethInc. embarked on the similar ''To Change Everything'' two-month tour of the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/blog/2015/06/15/to-change-everything-us-tour/ |title=To Change Everything US Tour |publisher=CrimeThInc. Ex-Workers Collective |accessdate=2015-10-22 |date=2015-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eastoregonian.com/eo/local-news/20150930/anarchy-comes-to-the-pendleton-art-center |title=Anarchists come to the Pendleton arts centre |publisher=East Oregonian |accessdate=2015-10-22 |date=2015-09-30}}</ref>
=== Music ===
CrimethInc. is associated with the [[North America]]n [[anarcho-punk]] scene because of its long relationship with notable musicians in the genre and its publishing of ''Inside Front'', a "journal of hardcore punk and anarchist action".<ref name="thompson-music">{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=Stacy |title=Punk Productions: Unfinished Business |publisher=SUNY Press |pages=109 |location=Albany |year=2004 |isbn=0-7914-6187-4 }}</ref> CrimethInc. releases include LPs, CDs, and 7"s from North American and European anarcho-punk, hardcore and [[anti-folk]] bands. Academic Stacy Thompson has described CrimethInc. as "exemplary of a more contemporary and nuanced approach" to the possible forms anarcho-punk could take to resist commodification through aesthetic expression.<ref name="thompson-music"/> However, Thompson does not consider the aesthetic choices of the collective to be substantially different from the anarcho- and [[crust punk]] bands released by fellow anarcho-punk collective ''[[Profane Existence]]'' in the mid-to-late 90s.<ref name="thompson-music"/>
==Philosophy== [[File:CrimethInc. - eclipse the past.png|thumb|140px|"Eclipse the past" inside front cover image from CrimethInc.'s ''Days of War, Nights of Love'' (2001). A philosophical theme of CrimethInc.'s writings is the rejection of the "exclusive, anti-[[subjectivity|subjective]]" nature of history, and the need to take active control of one's own life.]] {{quote |text=Crimethought is not any ideology or value system or lifestyle, but rather a way of challenging all ideologies and value systems and lifestyles—and, for the advanced agent, a way of making all ideologies, value systems, and lifestyles challenging. |sign =Crimethinc.com<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/texts/pastfeatures/purged.php |title=All Traveler Kids Purged From CrimethInc. Membership |accessdate=2008-01-20 |work=Crimethinc.com}}</ref>}} CrimethInc as a loose association represents a variety of political views; the CrimethInc. [[FAQ]] asserts that it has "no platform or ideology except that which could be generalized from the similarities between the beliefs and goals of the individuals who choose to be involved—and that is constantly in flux."<ref name="faq"/> "CrimethInc." is an anonymous tag, a means of constructing dynamic networks of support and communication within the anarchist movement, and as such anyone can publish under the name or create a poster using the logo; each agent or group of agents operate autonomously.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sims |first=Francwa |title=The Anacostia Diaries as It Is |year=2006 |isbn=1-4116-1888-2}}</ref> As well as the traditional anarchist opposition to the [[State (polity)|state]] and [[capitalism]], agents have, at times, advocated a [[straight edge]] lifestyle, the total supersession of [[gender role]]s,<ref name=gndr/> violent [[insurrection]] against the state,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/texts/atoz/antig8.php |title=Let Me Light My Cigarette on Your Burning Blockade |accessdate=2007-10-31 |work=Crimethinc.com}}</ref> and the [[refusal of work]].<ref name="vacation">{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/texts/insidefront/permanentvacation.php |title=How I Spent My Permanent Vacation |accessdate=2008-01-13 |last=D. |first=Brian |work=Crimethinc.com}}</ref>
CrimethInc. is influenced by the [[Situationist International]],<ref>{{cite journal |last=Lang |first=Daniel |date=May 2007 |title="Give Us the Dumpsters -Or- Give Us Life": Res Derilictae and the Trash of Free Trade |journal=Cultural Recycling |volume=3 |issue=1 |publisher=[[Other Voices (open-access journal of cultural criticism)|Other Voices]] |url=http://www.othervoices.org/3.1/dlang/index.php}}</ref> and has been described by scholar Martin Puchner as "inheritors of the political [[avant-garde]]",<ref>Puchner, Martin (2005). ''Poetry of the Revolution: Marx, Manifestos and the Avant-Gardes''. [[Princeton University Press]], Princeton and Oxford. 320pp., {{ISBN|978-0-691-12260-1}}.</ref> [[Ken Knabb]] has criticized CrimethInc. for presenting simplistic and in some cases false accounts of history in their manifesto ''Days of War, Nights of Love'', and for mythologizing themselves as "a pole of international subversion".<ref> {{cite web |url=http://libcom.org/library/crimethinc-comments-ken-knabb |title=Comments on CrimethInc. by Ken Knabb |publisher=Libcom.org |accessdate=2008-02-26 |last=Knabb |first=Ken |authorlink=Ken Knabb}} </ref> For their part, the authors of the book criticized the "exclusive, anti-[[subjectivity|subjective]]" nature of history as "paralyzing", advocating in its place a non-superstitious myth.<ref>''Days of War, Nights of Love'' (2001) , {{ISBN|0-9709101-0-X}}, p. 111–114</ref> The collective has expressed a strident anti-copyright stance and advocacy of the appropriation of texts and ideas of others, which has attracted criticism from academic philosopher George MacDonald Ross as an endorsement of plagiarism.<ref>{{cite conference|first=George |last=MacDonald Ross |title=Plagiarism really is a crime:a counterblast against anarchists and postmodernists (and others) |booktitle=Plagiarism: Prevention, Practice and Policies 2004 Conference |date=2004-05-10 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228450982_Plagiarism_really_is_a_crime_a_counterblast_against_anarchists_and_postmodernists_and_others |accessdate=2008-04-07 |format=PDF }}</ref> CrimethInc.'s N©! [[free license]] is known as an example of [[copyleft]]. It grants rights to individuals and none to corporations.<ref name="Keats2010">{{cite book|last=Keats|first=Jonathon|title=Virtual Words: Language on the Edge of Science and Technology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sBIOXJqqVEUC&pg=PA65|year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-975290-4|page=65}}</ref>
The active participants of CrimethInc. characterize it as a mindset and a way of life first and foremost, rather than as an organization ''per se''.<ref name="faq"/> Its main goal is to inspire people to take more active control of their own lives, becoming producers of culture and history instead of passive consumers.<ref>{{cite book |author=Summerisle |title=Times of Hate, Times of Joy, Lost Highway, Volume 1 |year=2005 |isbn=978-1-4116-6506-4 |publisher=Lulu |location=Morrisville, NC}}</ref><ref name="about">{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/about/ |title=About CWC: Index |work=Crimethinc.com |accessdate=2008-01-10}}</ref> Those who ascribe to the CrimethInc. philosophy advocate radical ways of living one's life to the end of eliminating the perceived inequities and tyrannies within society. Contributors to publications are generally not credited in respect of an anonymity asserted by participants to be one of the organization's primary values.<ref name="faq"/> The name "CrimethInc." itself is a satirical self-criticism about the hypocrisy of revolutionary propaganda (and other "margin-walking between contradictions"<ref name="faq">{{cite web |url=http://www.crimethinc.com/about/faq.html |title=Frequently Asked Questions |accessdate=2007-10-31 |work=Crimethinc.com}}</ref>) and a direct reference to the concept of "[[thoughtcrime]]" developed in [[George Orwell]]'s ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]''.<ref name="faq"/>

A '''cultural manager''' ({{lang-es|'''gestor cultural'''}}) is a person who is motivated by the improvement of [[art]], works independently and professionally with knowledge of the subject, and develops work as a mediator between governmental and/or private cultural institutions with artists from different areas to articulate their work in the market with promotion and national and international dissemination.<ref name=uoc>{{Cite web |url=http://gestiocultural.blogs.uoc.edu/2016/06/28/que-es-un-gestor-cultural-gestion-cultural/ |title=¿Qué es un gestor cultural? |trans-title=What is a Cultural Manager? |publisher=[[Open University of Catalonia]] |language=Spanish |date=28 June 2016 |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref>
The cultural manager works by looking for specific measures of success, always intending to improve the level of culture, seeking active cohesion between society, the governmental sector, the private sector, and the artists. The work of culture management poses learning challenges in diverse areas such as the administration of economic resources, training, and artistic communication.<ref name=uoc/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.educaweb.com/profesion/gestor-cultural-334/ |title=Gestor cultural |publisher=Educaweb |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref>
Cultural management is a new profession. A person who is dedicated to this work is characterized by having abilities to visualize and interpret talent, knowing how to establish a dialogue with artists to link them to cultural projects to develop.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2hHxeCA_ecYC&pg=PA13 |title=Gestión cultural: Entre conceptos lejanos y realidades cercanas |trans-title=Cultural Management: Between Distant Concepts and Nearby Realities |chapter=Acercando realidades a través de la gestión cultural |trans-chapter=Bringing Together Realities Through Cultural Management |first1=Silvia |last1=Aballay |first2=Carla Fernanda |last2=Avendaño Manelli |publisher=Eduvim |isbn=9789871518968 |pages=13-16 |language=Spanish |year=2010 |access-date=18 April 2018 |via=Google Books}}</ref>
Universities that offer degree programs in cultural management include the [[University of Antioquia]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.udea.edu.co/wps/portal/udea/web/inicio/institucional/unidades-academicas/facultades/artes/programas-academicos/programas-posgrado/contenido/asmenulateral/maestria-gestion-cultural/ |title=Maestría en Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Master's in Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Antioquia]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[Latin American Social Sciences Institute]],<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://en.unesco.org/creativity/sites/creativity/files/training%20in%20cultural%20management_es.pdf |title=Formación en gestión cultural y políticas culturales |trans-title=Training in Cultural Management and Cultural Policies |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |pages=53-54 |language=Spanish |year=2005 |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[University of Chile]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.uchile.cl/publicaciones/92958/revista-de-gestion-cultural |title=Revista de Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Journal of Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Chile]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[University of Córdoba (Spain)]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.uco.es/filosofiayletras/ggestioncultural/index.html |title=Grado de Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Degree in Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Córdoba (Spain)|University of Córdoba]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[National University of Colombia]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://agenciadenoticias.unal.edu.co/detalle/article/la-un-ofrecera-maestria-en-gestion-cultural.html |title=La U.N. ofrecerá Maestría en Gestión Cultural |trans-title=The U.N. Will Offer a Master's in Cultural Management |publisher=[[National University of Colombia]] |location=Manizales |language=Spanish |date=27 February 2018 |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[University of Barcelona]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ub.edu/web/ub/es/estudis/oferta_formativa/master_universitari/fitxa/G/M0304/index.html |title=Máster de Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Master's of Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Barcelona]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> and the [[University of Piura]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://udep.edu.pe/humanidades/mgc/ |title=Gestión Cultural |publisher=[[University of Piura]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref>

{{for|the Japanese band|doa (Japanese band)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = D.O.A. | background = group_or_band | image = DOA 2015.jpg | image_size = | caption = Mike Hodsall, Joe Keithley, and Paddy Duddy in the lower east side of Vancouver BC, 2015. Photographer: Tom Wiebe | origin = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | genre = [[Hardcore punk]], [[punk rock]] | occupation = | years_active = 1978–1990 • 2002–2013 • 2014–present | label = [[Alternative Tentacles]], [[Sudden Death Records|Sudden Death]] | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = [[Joe Keithley]]

[[Paddy Duddy]] | past_members = [[Chuck Biscuits]]

[[Brian Roy Goble]]

Dan Yaremko | }} '''D.O.A.''' is a Canadian [[punk rock]] band from [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. They are often referred to as the "founders" of [[hardcore punk]] along with [[Black Flag (band)|Black Flag]], [[Bad Brains]], [[Angry Samoans]], the [[Germs (band)|Germs]], [[Negative Trend]], and [[Middle Class (band)|Middle Class]]. Their second album ''[[Hardcore '81]]'' was thought by manyZach Baron, October 25, 2006, [http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/38721/Various_Artists_American_Hardcore_The_History_of_American_Punk_Ro Pitchfork Media] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070228155326/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/38721/Various_Artists_American_Hardcore_The_History_of_American_Punk_Ro |date=2007-02-28 }} to have been the first actual reference to the second wave of the American punk sound as [[hardcore punk|hardcore]]. Singer/guitarist [[Joey Keithley|Joey "Shithead" Keithley]] is the only founding member to have stayed in the band throughout its entire history, with original bassist [[Randy Rampage]] returning to the band twice after his original departure. D.O.A. has often released music on [[Jello Biafra]]'s [[Alternative Tentacles]] Records, and they have released an album titled ''[[Last Scream of the Missing Neighbors]]''. D.O.A. is known for its outspoken political opinions and has a history of performing for many causes and benefits. Its slogan is "Talk Minus Action Equals Zero." The band's lyrics and imagery frequently advocate [[anti-racism]], [[anti-globalization]], [[freedom of speech]], and [[environmentalism]]. Founder Joe Keithley is also the founder of [[Sudden Death Records]] which has released music by D.O.A. and several other bands including [[Pointed Sticks]] and [[Young Canadians]]. == History == ===Formation and early years (1977–1980)=== D.O.A. has its origins in [[The Skulls (Canadian band)|The Skulls]], an early Vancouver-area punk rock band that included future D.O.A members Joey "Shithead" Keithley, Brian "[[Wimpy Roy]]" Goble, and Ken "Dimwit" Montgomery. When the Skulls broke up after an ill-fated move to [[Toronto]], Keithley moved back to Vancouver and formed D.O.A. in early 1978 with himself on guitar, Dimwit's brother [[Chuck Biscuits]] on drums, [[Randy Rampage]] on bass, and a lead singer known only as "Harry Homo", who suggested the band's name. The band's first gig took place at the Japanese Hall in Vancouver on February 20 of that year, after which Harry Homo was sacked for an apparent lack of rhythm; Keithley then became the band's singer. A second guitarist named "Randy Romance" played briefly with the band in March 1978 before leaving. The band began playing frequently around Vancouver and added guitarist [[Brad Kent]] the following June. That summer, they recorded and self-released their first single, the four-song EP ''Disco Sucks''. The single soon topped the charts of the [[University of San Francisco]] radio station [[KUSF (defunct)|KUSF]], which prompted the band to begin touring down to [[San Francisco]]. They played their first shows there in August 1978 at [[Mabuhay Gardens]]. It was during this trip that the band first met [[Dead Kennedys]] frontman and future collaborator [[Jello Biafra]]. Kent was fired from the band in September and later that fall the band recorded and released their second single ''The Prisoner''. In May 1979, the band embarked on their first North American tour. Upon its completion they hired Vancouver journalist and activist Ken Lester as their manager. Lester booked another tour for them the following October, in the middle of which they flew back to Vancouver to open for [[The Clash]] at the [[Pacific Coliseum]]. They soon after released their third single, ''World War 3/Whatcha Gonna Do?''. In late 1979, they added second guitarist Dave Gregg. Soon after, Biscuits and Rampage left the band after a disastrous gig at the [[University of British Columbia]]'s Student Union Building and were replaced by Andy Graffiti and Simon "Stubby Pecker" Wilde on drums and bass, respectively. Keithley soon became dissatisfied with the band's performances with the new lineup, however, and Biscuits and Rampage both rejoined the band in March 1980. D.O.A. released their full-length debut ''[[Something Better Change]]'' on Friends Records in 1980 and continued touring the United States and Canada extensively. ===Hardcore 81 and further lineup changes (1981–1989)=== On April 22, 1981 the band released their second album ''[[Hardcore '81]]''; the record's title and its extensive North American promotional tour is sometimes credited with popularizing the term "[[hardcore punk]]". Randy Rampage was fired from the band on January 1, 1982 and was replaced by ex-Skulls drummer Dimwit on bass. After a short tour of California, Chuck Biscuits left the band and joined [[Black Flag (band)|Black Flag]]. Dimwit switched back to drums and [[Subhumans (Canadian band)|Subhumans]] singer [[Brian Roy Goble|Wimpy Roy]] was hired as the new bass player and second singer, leaving Keithley as the only remaining original member.{{cite book|first=Joey |last=Keithley |title=I, Shithead: A life in punk |publisher=Arsenal Pulp Press|year=2003|pages=107–111 |isbn=1-55152-148-2}} This lineup would last from 1982–1983 and later 1985-1986 and produced several notable releases, including the EP ''[[War on 45]]'' (now expanded into a full-length album). ''War on 45'' found the band expanding their sound with touches of funk and reggae, as well as making their anti-war and anti-imperialist political stance more clear. 1985's ''Let's Wreck The Party'' and 1987's ''True (North) Strong And Free'' saw the band taking on a more mainstream, hard-rock oriented production, but without watering down the band's political lyrical focus. Meanwhile, the band's lineup changes continued after ''Let's Wreck the Party'', with Dimwit replaced by [[Kerr Belliveau]]. Belliveau stayed only three weeks with the band but recorded the ''Expo Hurts Everyone'' 7" as well as two songs for ''True (North) Strong and Free'' before being replaced by [[Jon Card]] from [[Personality Crisis (band)|Personality Crisis]]. Dave Gregg quit in 1988 after D.O.A. fired their manager Ken Lester, to which he was very close. The band hired Chris Prohom from the [[Dayglo Abortions]] as a replacement.{{cite book|first=Joey |last=Keithley |title=I, Shithead: A life in punk |publisher=Arsenal Pulp Press|year=2003|pages=202|isbn=1-55152-148-2}} ===First breakup and reunion (1990–2002)=== 1990's ''Murder'' featured rawer, almost thrash-metal production, rather than their original basic punk sound. The same year also produced a collaboration with [[Dead Kennedys]] singer [[Jello Biafra]] with ''[[Last Scream of the Missing Neighbors]]''. In August 1990, Joey decided he was breaking up D.O.A. but, at the suggestion of promoter [[Dirk Dirksen]], they did a farewell tour of the West Coast, playing their "final" show on December 1, 1990 at the Commodore in Vancouver. In 1991, they released a posthumous live album entitled ''Talk Minus Action = 0'' while Keithley pursued an acting career.{{cite book|first=Joey |last=Keithley |title=I, Shithead: A life in punk |publisher=Arsenal Pulp Press|year=2003|pages=219–224|isbn=1-55152-148-2}} 19 months after D.O.A. broke up, Joey Shithead and Wimpy Roy had reunited as D.O.A in the summer of 1992. Fellow Canadian punk rock veteran [[John Wright (musician)|John Wright]] from [[NoMeansNo]] suggested they hire [[Ken Jensen]] from [[Red Tide (band)|Red Tide]] as the new drummer, which they did. The new lineup released an EP and two albums in the early 1990s, ''[[13 Flavours Of Doom]]'' and ''Loggerheads''. These albums found the band replacing the more hard-rock oriented sound of the 1980s with a return to punk rock, although it was a heavier, tighter brand of punk than their earlier work. These albums were produced by Wright, who also played keyboards on the recordings. The band then added [[Ford Pier]] on guitar and vocals. Tragedy struck in 1995 when drummer Ken Jensen died in a house fire. The "Ken Jensen Memorial Single" EP was released on Alternative Tentacles, including two tracks each from D.O.A. and Red Tide. With John Wright filling in on drums, ninth full-length ''The Black Spot'' was recorded. The album featured a more basic, sing-along type punk rock sound that was reminiscent of the band's late 1970s and early 1980s output. The late 1990s found the band's lineup in turmoil, with Wimpy Roy leaving the band after a decade and a half of service. Keithley experimented with different bassists and drummers and released the album ''Festival Of Atheists'' in 1998. By the early 2000s, the band had found a permanent drummer in the form of The Great Baldini. In 2002, Keithley put out his first solo album, ''Beat Trash'', and original bassist Randy Rampage returned to the band after nearly 20 years for the ''Win The Battle'' album. However, the reunion did not last, with Rampage leaving the band again after the recording of the album, to be replaced by Dan Yaremko. ''The Lost Tapes'' was the first release on Keithley's revived Sudden Death label, followed by ''Festival Of Atheists''. During this period, Keithley also oversaw the re-release of the band's classic early records on Sudden Death, several of which had been out of print for many years. ===Later years and second hiatus (2003–2013)=== In 2003, Vancouver Mayor [[Larry Campbell]] declared December 21 to be "D.O.A. Day" in honour of the band's 25th anniversary.{{Cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/article-69929/d-o-a-s-punk-veterans-won-t-give-up-the-fight|title=D.O.A.'s punk veterans won't give up the fight|accessdate=2007-05-20|publisher=The Georgia Straight|first=John|last=Lucas}} In the same year, the band released a career-spanning retrospective entitled ''War And Peace''. 2004 found the band releasing the ska-flavoured ''Live Free or Die''. In 2006, Randy Rampage rejoined D.O.A. for his 3rd stint in the band. The lineup remained stable until 2008, when The Great Baldini left the band to be replaced by new drummer James Hayden. Also in 2008, it was announced that [[Bob Rock]], of [[Metallica]] fame would be producing the band's next album in time for their 30th anniversary.{{cite web|url=http://www.punknews.org/article/27566|title=D.O.A. recording with Bob Rock|website=Punknews.org|accessdate=16 August 2018}} James Hayden quit before D.O.A. started to record to be replaced by [[Floor Tom Jones]] In September 2008, D.O.A. released ''Northern Avenger'' and embarked on their 30th anniversary tour. On the eve of the tour, it was announced that Randy Rampage was being replaced by Dan Yaremko once again. D.O.A. played several dates in the summer of 2009 as part of the Van's Warped Tour 2009. On May 1, 2010, D.O.A. released their fourteenth full-length album ''Talk Minus Action = Zero'' (a similarly titled live album ''Talk Minus Action Equals Zero'' had previously been released in 1990). Drummer Jesse Pinner (of the band [[Raised by Apes]]) took the place of Floor Tom Jones beginning on D.O.A.'s subsequent August 2010 tour due to Floor Tom Jones' commitments to his job at [[Canada Post]].{{Cite web |url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=22342223&blogId=538222802 |title="Pincher is going across canada with punkrock legends D.O.A." on the "Raised by Apes" blog |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207065936/http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view |archivedate=2009-02-07 |df= }} In 2012, Joe announced that he would be seeking nomination as an NDP candidate in the B.C. provincial election.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/punk-rocker-runs-for-ndp-nomination/article4496440/|title=Punk rocker runs for NDP nomination|accessdate=16 August 2018|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]}} As a result, D.O.A. announced an indefinite hiatus, and began their farewell tour on January 18, 2013 in celebration of the band's thirty-five year anniversary.{{cite web|url=http://www.liveatrickshaw.com/224/doas-farewell-show/|title=Rickshaw Theatre - Shows|website=Liveatrickshaw.com|accessdate=16 August 2018}} ===Second reunion and recent activity (2014–present)=== On September 22, 2014, Keithley officially announced on the Sudden Death Records website that he had decided to reform the band with Paddy Duddy on drums and Mike "Maggot" Hodsall on bass, and would be embarking on a Canadian tour in October in support of the recently released live album, ''Welcome To Chinatown''. This lineup recorded and released the studio album ''Hard Rain Falling'' in 2015. In April 2016, the band released a new version of "Fucked Up Ronnie" entitled "Fucked Up Donald" (referring to the 2016 [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential nominee [[Donald Trump]]) as a single. === Timeline === {{#tag:timeline| ImageSize = width:800 height:auto barincrement:18 PlotArea = left:150 bottom:70 top:10 right:25 Alignbars = justify DateFormat = mm/dd/yyyy
